title: Object Property Matching utilizing the Overlap between Imported Ontologies

author: Benjamin Zapilko, GESIS - Leibniz Institute for the Social Sciences

segmentation: Welcome everybody to my talk.
I'm Ben Supplica from Jesus and today I will talk about an approach for object property matching utilizing the overlap between imported ontologies.
The approach is based on.
The idea has come out from a.
Domain specific use case from the social Sciences, but also from other domains where open government data like statistical data for example, is used.
To get insights out of the data to doing research, to do research with the data.
As we can see, a small snippet of the data how it looks like and just one data entry of an observation.
But typical for this kind of data is that it has a very distributed structure.
So we have object properties that link to instances inside of other datasets.
Therefore we have different namespaces, different UI paths, and different schemas to deal with.
So far so good, but one of the main use cases.
And research domains is not only to analyze one data set for its own.
But to merge and to integrate datasets to doing some kind of comparative analysis.
For example, population numbers compared to unemployment rates or compared to poverty rates, and for this kind of analysis, data has to be integrated and to be merged.
When looking at link datasets and seeing OK, there are object properties that link to other code lists which are again other datasets.
In theory it seems to be a good choice to let instance matches schema matches or ontology matches run on this kind of data.
We had done some some pre tests and detected that it's not that easy.
And that especially when object properties are labeled highly different than no correspondence between these properties can be found.
For example, in one data set, the object property is clear and in the other data set the object property is called location.
Then, although both link to country lists.
No correspondence between these properties can be found.
And Furthermore useful information that might ease.
The finding of such in correspondence is often not considered by current matching tools.
So in this case, the information that both code lists contain a class refering to the label Luxemburg would help to find the particular correspondence between the object properties.
So as any everybody can see.
This room is relatively easy for people an for domain experts.
Of course 2 to see.
OK there are both country lists.
This is the same.
This is a matching between Geo and location.
But actually it's not that easy.

It's easy to decide whether a correspondence is correct or is not correct for a domain expert, but it's not that easy to know whether all potential correct correspondences between two datasets have been detected automatically.
So the recall is highly important.
In order to merge and integrate the datasets.
So far from the actual example from statistical data, what we have done with the problem is to formalize this, end to abstract it to on top.
Oh, geez.
And in this case.
We have instances of classes of ontology.
They hold object properties P that link not to classes or individuals from the same ontology, but from another ontology which we recall as imported ontology.
So what we state's problem is that correspondences between object properties may be missed.
When when linked classes?
From the object properties are part of external imported ontologies, so they are often be missed and therefore the matching between the object properties is not detected.
Why are matching systems not trained directly against this and problem?
OK, it's a very specific problem.
And.
Therefore, no datasets exist in current established benchmark that can.
That can a matching systems be evaluated against.
What we have done with the problem So what we tried to do to address this problem.
Is.
Yeah, no correspondence has been detected, right?
What we try to do is.
To utilize the overlap.
Between.
The important ontologies.
In order to get inside and an indicator for whether we have a correspondence.
Between the object properties P, how do we?
To do this, we want to do this.
By matching.
Imported ontologies so the classes all entities of the imported ontologies are being matched.
Based on the result, correspondence is an overlap score is computed.
And the overlap score indicates.
That between the object properties that link.
The classes of the important ontologies between these properties is a correspondence.
We have implemented this in a.
Five step algorithm.
The first step to do this is.
To identify the important ontologies first.
So when we have datasets we need to know what are imported ontologies, what belongs to the data set itself.
And whatnot.
So this is done by grouping.
All objects.
Inside the input ontologies, in order to to according to their namespaces and that you arise in order to order the imported ontologies.
And the next step.
The input ontologies are matched for themselves separately with any given instance based matcher, 'cause we use the matching system as a black box, we don't do.
We don't.
Do anything with the matching process that the matching system is doing is run by himself.
And the third step we are doing exactly the same with all the identified imported ontologies.
So each pair of imported ontologies is matched with each other because we don't know which pairs belong together or which which pairs are right or which are wrong.
Based on all these detected.
Correspondances we calculate the overlap score between each pair of imported ontologies.
For this overlap value we are using the Jaccard coefficient.
Which is a established measure for computing overlap between sets.
And the result is.
Some overlap score.
Between each pair of correspondence between each pair of imported ontologies is then be seen as an object property linking as far.
It is as far as there is any kind of overlap.
If the overlap is 0, then we say OK, there is no correspondence between the linking object properties.
We have evaluated this approach in two scenarios.
One artificially created benchmark for statistical data.
I will say a few more words to this benchmark on the next slides and the other scenario was using real world data from euro Staten from OECD.
The reference alignment between these.
Datasets has been done by three domain experts in order that we can measure an measure and precision.
Recall and F measure precisely.
And the tools we were using were Falcon, IO and agreement maker.
Both of them delivered pretty good results and previous ontology alignment evaluations and.
Since they they consider object similarities and agreement, make consists contains an instance match we.
Seems we thought these were a good choice to use for the evaluation.
Regarding the benchmark for statistical data, or why do we have to do on our own benchmark?
The problem was that no suitable benchmark exists that that considers the particular problems in the data structure.
We wanted to investigate.
When when creating our own benchmark, of course we oriented on established benchmarks.
How did the other ones do this?
Of course, so we oriented on the OAI benchmark and on the Iamb benchmark.
That means we created one seed ontology.
We randomly randomly populated it with instances.
And then we generated kinds of variations that consider a particular patterns and characteristics.
We wanted to investigate during the evaluation.
Here's an example class of the SEAT ontology which looks very similar to the real world example I've shown on the 1st slide.
So we have a seat ontology containing different data entries that all refer to the object properties.
Refer again to instances of separated of imported ontologies.
OK, so if done the evaluation and first run we let agreement make on Falcon IO process and match the ontologies without any.
Yeah as they are.
And in the second run, the object property matching run.
We have we process the additional matching tasks that come with matching the imported ontologies separately.
As you can see in the results, we get a pretty good improvement and recall.
That's exactly what we wanted up to two times, but you can also see that there is, especially when dealing with real world data.
A in this case a high loss of precision.
And so we ask ourselves, OK?
We're just the loss of precision come from and of course a lot of precision occurs when there are false correspondences inside the result.
So we tried to address this problem.
We wanted to eliminate the false positives in order to.
To see if we, whether we can, whether we can improve the results, or whether we can tackle the loss of precision.
And so we did.
Decided to.
Try with different similarity measures.
Try some variants of the chukar coefficient because one of the problems is that Chicago coefficient can get very unbalanced.
Especially when the sets that are taken into account budget car are very of a very different size.
For the particular case of geographical object properties, we had the case that one object property was linking to a.
To an imported ontology that contained about 40 classes and the other one linked to properties contained 4000 classes.
And that's the reason why Shikar gets very, very slow.
Very, very little values.
So we tried the different.
Massage measures and took a look at the calculated overlap scores.
And we can see for the examples of agreement maker OK by choosing a threshold.
It might get better to at might be possible to eliminate the false positive correspondence.
But when taking a look.
At.
Results for Falcon.
I always seen.
OK, that must not always be the case, and it gets very difficult because the difference like on matters of course influence also the overlap scores for the false positive.
Detected correspondences, so our feeling was that experimenting with different similarity similarity measures.
It was not that relevant, in contrast to wisely choose a suitable matching system advisory, configure it.
So we think it's more likely to.
To try to avoid the false positives in order to.
Try to eliminate them afterwards.
Yet to conclude.
We have presented an instance based objective object property matching approach.
What we have done is that we are utilizing the overlap between the imported ontologies and especially we included classes.
From the imported ontologies that are not linked inside of the data set themselves.
So we take and we took the complete.
Imported ontologies into account.
The results were regarding recall pretty good, but the loss in precision.
We still have to tackle.
Maybe a large evaluation may bring more insights on this.
This problem and any instance based matching system can be applied.
Since the matching system is used as a black box in our approach.
Our future work had two directions.
One Direction is the object property matching approach itself.

So as I mentioned, we want to do a larger evaluation to get more more significant results, and although we are not very convinced yet considering the different similarity measures, this is definitely a point we want to address in the future, and we want to.

I'm not trying to get more insight on this issue, the other direction for future work is to extend the benchmark for statistical data, not only for our own purpose to include more object properties with more more classifications.
More diverse code lists in order to.
To improve the difficulty of different variants, we want to include more variants, and we want to make it applicable for other purposes, not only for our matching approach.
Well that's it, and thanks for your attention and I'm ready for your questions.
